useCases.title: Habitual Actions & Routines
useCases.mainExample: I work from home every day.
moreExamples: She drinks coffee every morning.
They play tennis on Saturdays.
He watches TV in the evening.
We eat dinner at 7pm.
The shop opens at 9am.
useCases.note: Use Present Simple for routines and habits that happen regularly.

useCases.title: General Truths & Facts
useCases.mainExample: Water boils at 100Â°C.
moreExamples: The sun rises in the east.
Cats love milk.
London is the capital of England.
Two plus two equals four.
Birds fly south in winter.
useCases.note: Use for permanent facts and scientific truths that are always true.

useCases.title: Timetables & Schedules
useCases.mainExample: The train leaves at 6:30pm.
moreExamples: The film starts at 8 o'clock.
School finishes at 3pm.
The plane departs at midnight.
The museum opens at 10am.
The concert begins at 7:30.
useCases.note: Use for fixed schedules and timetables (public transport, events).

useCases.title: Time Conjunctions (Future Meaning)
useCases.mainExample: I'll call you when I get home.
moreExamples: We'll start as soon as everyone arrives.
She'll be happy when she hears the news.
Before you leave, please lock the door.
After he finishes work, he goes to the gym.
I'll wait until you come back.
useCases.note: After time conjunctions, use Present Simple (not will) for future events.

useCases.title: State Verbs
useCases.mainExample: I love chocolate.
moreExamples: She knows the answer.
They believe in ghosts.
He understands the problem.
We own a car.
I prefer tea to coffee.
useCases.note: State verbs (love, know, believe, understand, own, prefer) rarely use continuous forms.

useCases.title: Instructions & Directions
useCases.mainExample: You turn left at the traffic lights.
moreExamples: First, you add the sugar.
Then, you mix everything together.
You go straight ahead for 200 meters.
You take the second exit at the roundabout.
Finally, you bake it for 20 minutes.
useCases.note: Use Present Simple for giving instructions and directions.

useCases.title: Sports Commentary
useCases.mainExample: Messi passes to Ronaldo, he shoots, he scores!
moreExamples: Federer serves, Nadal returns the ball.
Hamilton takes the lead!
The goalkeeper saves the penalty.
She wins the race!
He breaks the record!
useCases.note: Use Present Simple for live sports commentary and narration.

useCases.title: Newspaper Headlines
useCases.mainExample: Prime Minister announces new policy.
moreExamples: Scientists discover new planet.
Company launches innovative product.
Team wins championship.
Government introduces tax reforms.
Actor receives prestigious award.
useCases.note: Headlines often use Present Simple for past events to make them more immediate and dramatic.

useCases.title: Actions Happening Now
useCases.mainExample: She is reading a book right now.
moreExamples: They are watching TV at the moment.
I am working on a project.
He is cooking dinner currently.
We are studying English.
The children are playing in the garden.
useCases.note: Use for actions in progress at the exact moment of speaking.

useCases.title: Temporary Situations
useCases.mainExample: I'm staying with my parents this week.
moreExamples: She's working in London for a few months.
They're living in a hotel while their house is being renovated.
He's using his brother's car this week.
We're renting an apartment temporarily.
I'm taking the bus while my car is being repaired.
useCases.note: Use for temporary situations that are not permanent.

useCases.title: Arranged Future Plans
useCases.mainExample: I'm meeting Tom tomorrow at 6pm.
moreExamples: We're having dinner with friends tonight.
She's flying to Paris next week.
They're getting married next year.
He's starting his new job on Monday.
I'm seeing the doctor tomorrow morning.
useCases.note: Use for definite arrangements and plans (especially with specific time/place).

useCases.title: Changing Situations
useCases.mainExample: The climate is getting warmer every year.
moreExamples: Technology is developing rapidly.
House prices are rising.
The situation is improving.
My English is getting better.
The world's population is increasing.
useCases.note: Use for situations that are changing or developing over time.

useCases.title: Trends & Developments
useCases.mainExample: More people are working from home nowadays.
moreExamples: Fewer young people are buying houses these days.
Companies are investing more in renewable energy.
Students are using AI tools more frequently.
People are becoming more health-conscious.
Businesses are adopting digital technologies.
useCases.note: Use for describing current trends and ongoing changes in society.

useCases.title: Annoying Habits (with always)
useCases.mainExample: He's always losing his keys!
moreExamples: She's constantly complaining about everything.
They're always arriving late.
You're forever leaving the lights on.
He's continually interrupting me.
She's always forgetting her phone.
useCases.note: Use Present Continuous with 'always/constantly' to express annoyance about repeated actions.

useCases.title: Background Actions in Stories
useCases.mainExample: The sun was shining and birds were singing.
moreExamples: I was walking down the street when I saw him.
While she was cooking, the phone rang.
They were having dinner when the earthquake struck.
He was watching TV while his wife was reading.
Rain was falling and wind was blowing.
useCases.note: Use for setting the scene or describing background actions in narratives.

useCases.title: Extended Activities (Around Now)
useCases.mainExample: I'm reading an interesting book at the moment.
moreExamples: She's learning to drive these days.
They're building a new house this year.
He's writing a novel.
We're renovating our flat.
I'm doing a course in graphic design.
useCases.note: Use for activities in progress over an extended period (not necessarily happening right now).

useCases.title: For & Since (Duration)
useCases.mainExample: I have lived here for five years.
moreExamples: She has worked at the company since 2020.
We have known each other for ten years.
They have been married since 1995.
He has owned this car for six months.
I have studied English since I was a child.
useCases.note: FOR = period of time (5 years, 3 months). SINCE = starting point (2020, Monday, I was born).

useCases.title: Life Experience (Ever, Never, Always)
useCases.mainExample: I have never eaten sushi.
moreExamples: Have you ever been to Japan?
She has visited Paris three times.
They have never seen snow.
He has always wanted to learn Spanish.
We have been to that restaurant before.
useCases.note: Use for experiences up to now (time not important). EVER = in your life. NEVER = not in your life.

useCases.title: Superlative Expressions (First Time, Best, Worst)
useCases.mainExample: This is the first time I have visited London.
moreExamples: It's the best film I have ever seen.
This is the worst meal I have ever had.
She's the most interesting person I have ever met.
It's the third time he has been late this week.
This is the biggest fish I have ever caught.
useCases.note: After superlatives and 'the first/second/third time', use Present Perfect.

useCases.title: Yet (in Questions & Negatives)
useCases.mainExample: Have you finished your homework yet?
moreExamples: I haven't seen that film yet.
She hasn't replied to my email yet.
Have they arrived yet?
He hasn't made a decision yet.
Has the train left yet?
useCases.note: YET = until now (questions & negatives). Goes at the END of the sentence.

useCases.title: Just (Very Recent Actions)
useCases.mainExample: I have just finished my work.
moreExamples: She has just left the office.
They have just arrived home.
He has just called me.
We have just heard the news.
The train has just departed.
useCases.note: JUST = very recently (a few minutes/moments ago). Goes BEFORE the past participle.

useCases.title: Lately & Recently (Recent Period)
useCases.mainExample: I have been very busy lately.
moreExamples: She has worked hard recently.
They haven't seen each other lately.
Have you been to the cinema recently?
He has been feeling tired lately.
We have had a lot of rain recently.
useCases.note: LATELY & RECENTLY = in the recent period up to now. Both go at the END of the sentence.

useCases.title: Recent Events & News
useCases.mainExample: Scientists have discovered a new planet.
moreExamples: The government has announced new policies.
A famous actor has died.
The company has launched a new product.
Researchers have found a cure for the disease.
The team has won the championship.
useCases.note: Use Present Perfect to announce recent news events (connection to present).

useCases.title: Unfinished Time (This Week, Today, This Year)
useCases.mainExample: I have seen him three times this week.
moreExamples: She has called me twice today.
They have visited us several times this month.
He has been to the gym four times this week.
We have had two meetings today.
I have read five books this year.
useCases.note: Use Present Perfect with unfinished time periods (this week is not finished yet).

useCases.title: For & Since (Ongoing Duration)
useCases.mainExample: I have been working here for five years.
moreExamples: She has been studying English since 2020.
They have been waiting for two hours.
He has been living in London for ten years.
We have been playing tennis since 3pm.
I have been learning Spanish for six months.
useCases.note: Emphasizes DURATION and CONTINUITY. Action started in the past and continues now.

useCases.title: How Long Questions
useCases.mainExample: How long have you been waiting?
moreExamples: How long has she been working there?
How long have they been living here?
How long has he been studying?
How long have you been learning English?
How long has it been raining?
useCases.note: Use 'How long + Present Perfect Continuous' to ask about duration.

useCases.title: Recently, Lately (Ongoing Activities)
useCases.mainExample: I have been feeling very tired lately.
moreExamples: She has been working hard recently.
They have been arguing a lot lately.
He has been exercising regularly recently.
We have been eating healthily lately.
What have you been doing recently?
useCases.note: Use for repeated or ongoing activities in the recent period.

useCases.title: Actions Just Finished (Visible Results)
useCases.mainExample: You're sweating! Have you been running?
moreExamples: Your hands are dirty. Have you been gardening?
She's exhausted. She has been working all day.
The ground is wet. It has been raining.
His eyes are red. He has been crying.
You look tired. Have you been studying all night?
useCases.note: Use when the activity has just stopped and there are VISIBLE RESULTS in the present.

useCases.title: Repeated Actions (Over Time)
useCases.mainExample: I have been calling you all morning!
moreExamples: She has been asking the same question repeatedly.
They have been trying to contact us for days.
He has been sending me emails all week.
We have been practicing every day.
I have been visiting my grandmother regularly.
useCases.note: Use for repeated actions over a period of time (emphasizes repetition).

useCases.title: Unfinished Time Periods
useCases.mainExample: I have been working on this project all week.
moreExamples: She has been preparing for her exam all month.
They have been renovating their house this year.
He has been attending meetings all day today.
We have been dealing with problems all morning.
I have been reading this book all evening.
useCases.note: Use with unfinished time periods to emphasize ongoing activity.

useCases.title: Temporary vs Permanent Situations
useCases.mainExample: I have been living in a hotel (temporary).
moreExamples: She has been using her brother's car (temporary).
They have been staying with friends (temporary).
He has been working from home (temporary arrangement).
We have been renting an apartment (not permanent).
I have been taking the bus (while car is broken).
useCases.note: Use Present Perfect Continuous for TEMPORARY situations. Use Present Perfect Simple for permanent.

useCases.title: Annoying Habits (Complaint)
useCases.mainExample: Who has been using my computer?!
moreExamples: Someone has been eating my chocolate!
Who has been moving my things?
He has been leaving dirty dishes in the sink again!
They have been making noise all night!
You have been spending too much money!
useCases.note: Use to express annoyance or make complaints about recent actions (evidence remains).

useCases.title: Completed Actions (Specific Time)
useCases.mainExample: I saw that film yesterday.
moreExamples: She went to Paris last year.
They bought a house in 2020.
He finished university in 2019.
We met ten years ago.
I visited my grandmother last week.
useCases.note: Use for finished actions at a specific time in the past (time is mentioned or implied).

useCases.title: Sequences of Past Actions
useCases.mainExample: I woke up, had breakfast, and left for work.
moreExamples: She opened the door, walked in, and sat down.
They arrived, checked in, and went to their room.
He took out his phone, dialed the number, and waited.
We entered the building, climbed the stairs, and found the office.
I finished work, drove home, and cooked dinner.
useCases.note: Use for a series of completed actions in chronological order.

useCases.title: Past Habits & States (Used To)
useCases.mainExample: I lived in London when I was young.
moreExamples: She played tennis every weekend (but doesn't now).
They went to the beach every summer.
He smoked, but he quit five years ago.
We always visited our grandparents on Sundays.
I had long hair when I was a teenager.
useCases.note: Use for past habits or states that are no longer true (can use 'used to' or Past Simple).

useCases.title: Historical Facts & Dates
useCases.mainExample: World War II ended in 1945.
moreExamples: Shakespeare wrote Hamlet.
The Romans built Hadrian's Wall.
Columbus discovered America in 1492.
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989.
Einstein published his theory of relativity in 1905.
useCases.note: Use for historical events and facts (finished time in the past).

useCases.title: Stories & Narratives
useCases.mainExample: Once upon a time, there lived a king.
moreExamples: She walked into the room and saw a strange man.
The phone rang, so I answered it.
He looked out the window and noticed something unusual.
They heard a noise and went to investigate.
I turned around and there he was.
useCases.note: Use Past Simple for the main events in stories (Past Continuous for background).

useCases.title: How Long (Finished Period)
useCases.mainExample: I worked there for five years (but I left).
moreExamples: She lived in Paris for ten years (before moving).
They were married for twenty years (then divorced).
He studied at that university for four years (then graduated).
We rented that flat for two years (before buying a house).
I knew her for a long time (but we lost touch).
useCases.note: Use Past Simple when the period is FINISHED. Compare: 'I worked there for 5 years' (finished) vs 'I have worked there for 5 years' (still working).

useCases.title: Past Questions (When, What Time)
useCases.mainExample: When did you arrive?
moreExamples: What time did the film start?
Where did you go last summer?
How did you get here?
Who did you see at the party?
Why did she leave early?
useCases.note: Use Past Simple in questions about specific past times or events.

useCases.title: Dead People's Lives
useCases.mainExample: Picasso painted many masterpieces.
moreExamples: Mozart composed beautiful music.
Einstein was a brilliant scientist.
Gandhi fought for independence.
Shakespeare wrote 37 plays.
Beethoven created nine symphonies.
useCases.note: Always use Past Simple for dead people's achievements (their life is a finished period).

useCases.title: Interrupted Actions (When)
useCases.mainExample: I was watching TV when the phone rang.
moreExamples: She was cooking when her friends arrived.
They were playing tennis when it started raining.
He was reading when I called.
We were having dinner when the lights went out.
I was sleeping when the alarm went off.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous for the LONGER background action. Past Simple for the SHORT interrupting action.

useCases.title: Parallel Actions (While)
useCases.mainExample: While I was studying, my brother was playing video games.
moreExamples: She was cooking while he was setting the table.
They were watching TV while the children were sleeping.
I was reading while my wife was working.
He was driving while she was looking at the map.
We were dancing while the band was playing.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous for TWO actions happening at the SAME TIME (both continuous).

useCases.title: Specific Time in the Past
useCases.mainExample: At 8pm last night, I was having dinner.
moreExamples: This time yesterday, I was flying to New York.
At midnight, they were still working.
At 3pm, she was attending a meeting.
Yesterday at this time, we were sitting on the beach.
At 7am, he was already running in the park.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous for actions IN PROGRESS at a specific past time.

useCases.title: Setting the Scene (Descriptions)
useCases.mainExample: The sun was shining and birds were singing.
moreExamples: Rain was falling and wind was blowing.
People were walking in the park and children were playing.
Music was playing and everyone was dancing.
The fire was burning and smoke was rising.
Lights were flashing and sirens were sounding.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous to set the scene or describe the atmosphere in stories.

useCases.title: Gradual Changes in the Past
useCases.mainExample: The weather was getting worse.
moreExamples: House prices were rising rapidly.
The situation was improving.
His health was deteriorating.
The economy was growing.
Technology was developing quickly.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous for changes and developments that were in progress in the past.

useCases.title: Repeated Actions (Always - Complaint)
useCases.mainExample: He was always losing his keys!
moreExamples: She was constantly complaining.
They were always arriving late.
You were forever forgetting things.
He was continually interrupting.
She was always talking on the phone.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous with 'always/constantly' to express annoyance about past habits.

useCases.title: Polite Questions & Requests
useCases.mainExample: I was wondering if you could help me.
moreExamples: I was hoping you might have time to talk.
I was thinking we could meet for coffee.
We were wondering if you'd like to join us.
I was hoping to ask you a favor.
I was just wanting to check something.
useCases.note: Use Past Continuous to make polite requests or introduce topics gently.

useCases.title: Plans That Didn't Happen
useCases.mainExample: I was going to call you, but I forgot.
moreExamples: She was planning to visit, but she got sick.
They were going to buy a house, but changed their minds.
He was hoping to get promoted, but it didn't happen.
We were thinking of moving, but decided to stay.
I was about to leave when you arrived.
useCases.note: Use 'was/were going to' or 'was/were planning to' for unfulfilled past intentions.

useCases.title: Earlier Past Action (Before)
useCases.mainExample: When I arrived, they had already left.
moreExamples: She had finished her work before she went home.
By the time we got there, the film had started.
He had never seen snow before he moved to Canada.
They had eaten all the food before we arrived.
I had read the book before I saw the film.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect for the EARLIER action. Past Simple for the LATER action.

useCases.title: Giving Reasons for Past Situations
useCases.mainExample: I was tired because I had worked all day.
moreExamples: She was angry because he had lied to her.
They were excited because they had won the lottery.
He was nervous because he had never flown before.
We were surprised because we had expected different news.
I was confused because no one had explained it to me.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect to explain the reason for a past situation or feeling.

useCases.title: By + Past Time
useCases.mainExample: By 2020, he had worked there for ten years.
moreExamples: By the age of 25, she had visited 30 countries.
By midnight, they had finished the project.
By the end of the year, we had sold 1000 units.
By 8pm, I had completed all my tasks.
By the time she was 18, she had already graduated.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect with 'by' to show something was completed before a specific past time.

useCases.title: Third Conditional (Unreal Past)
useCases.mainExample: If I had known, I would have come earlier.
moreExamples: If she had studied harder, she would have passed the exam.
If they had left earlier, they wouldn't have missed the train.
If he had told me, I could have helped.
If we had known about the traffic, we would have taken another route.
If you had asked me, I would have said yes.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect in the 'if' clause of Third Conditionals (impossible past situations).

useCases.title: Reported Speech (Past Perfect Shift)
useCases.mainExample: She said she had seen the film.
moreExamples: He told me he had finished the work.
They explained they had already eaten.
She mentioned she had been to Paris before.
He admitted he had made a mistake.
They said they had never tried sushi.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect in reported speech when the reporting verb is in the past (said, told, explained).

useCases.title: Wishes About the Past
useCases.mainExample: I wish I had studied harder.
moreExamples: She wishes she had accepted the job offer.
They wish they had bought the house.
He wishes he had told her the truth.
We wish we had traveled more.
I wish I hadn't said that.
useCases.note: Use 'wish + Past Perfect' for regrets about the past (things you can't change).

useCases.title: Just, Already, Yet (in the Past)
useCases.mainExample: The train had just left when we arrived.
moreExamples: She had already gone to bed when I called.
They hadn't finished yet when the bell rang.
He had just started eating when the doorbell rang.
We had already left when they arrived.
I hadn't seen him yet when he called my name.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect with just/already/yet to show very recent completion before another past action.

useCases.title: Past Experience Before Another Past Time
useCases.mainExample: It was the first time I had ever flown.
moreExamples: It was the best meal I had ever eaten.
It was the worst film I had ever seen.
It was the third time she had visited London.
It was the most interesting book I had ever read.
It was the only time I had been abroad.
useCases.note: Use Past Perfect after 'it was the first/best/worst/only time' (experience up to that past moment).

useCases.title: Duration Before Past Action
useCases.mainExample: I was tired because I had been working all day.
moreExamples: She was exhausted because she had been running for an hour.
The ground was wet because it had been raining.
They were hungry because they had been waiting for ages.
My eyes hurt because I had been reading for hours.
He was sweating because he had been exercising.
useCases.note: Use to show HOW LONG an action continued before another past action. Emphasizes DURATION.

useCases.title: Visible Evidence in the Past
useCases.mainExample: His hands were dirty because he had been gardening.
moreExamples: Her eyes were red because she had been crying.
The roads were icy because it had been snowing.
He was out of breath because he had been running.
The kitchen was a mess because she had been cooking.
They looked tired because they had been traveling all night.
useCases.note: Use when there was VISIBLE EVIDENCE in the past of a recently finished activity.

useCases.title: How Long Questions (Past Context)
useCases.mainExample: How long had you been waiting when the bus finally arrived?
moreExamples: How long had she been studying before she passed the exam?
How long had they been living there when they decided to move?
How long had he been working when he got promoted?
How long had you been learning English before you moved here?
How long had it been raining when you left?
useCases.note: Use 'How long + had + been + -ing' to ask about duration up to a past moment.

useCases.title: Explaining Past Situations
useCases.mainExample: She knew the city well because she had been living there for years.
moreExamples: He spoke fluent Spanish because he had been studying it for ages.
They were experts because they had been doing it for decades.
I understood the problem because I had been dealing with it all week.
She was confident because she had been preparing for months.
We were ready because we had been planning for a long time.
useCases.note: Use to explain a past situation by showing the ONGOING activity that led to it.

useCases.title: Repeated Actions Before Past Moment
useCases.mainExample: I had been calling you all morning before you finally answered.
moreExamples: She had been asking the same question repeatedly before she got an answer.
They had been trying to contact us for days before we replied.
He had been sending me emails all week before I responded.
We had been attempting to fix it for hours before it finally worked.
I had been knocking on the door for ages before someone opened it.
useCases.note: Use to emphasize REPEATED actions over a period up to a past moment.

useCases.title: Recent Continuous Action in Past
useCases.mainExample: The streets were empty because everyone had been watching the match.
moreExamples: The office was quiet because everyone had been working from home.
The shops were busy because people had been preparing for Christmas.
The traffic was terrible because workers had been leaving early.
The park was crowded because families had been enjoying the weather.
The roads were blocked because protesters had been demonstrating.
useCases.note: Use to describe an activity that had been continuing recently in the past.

useCases.title: Complaints About Past Situations
useCases.mainExample: Someone had been using my computer!
moreExamples: Who had been eating my chocolate?
They had been making noise all night!
He had been moving my things again!
Someone had been smoking in here!
Who had been going through my files?
useCases.note: Use to express annoyance about discovered past actions (evidence remains).

useCases.title: Background to Past Events
useCases.mainExample: The company failed because it had been losing money for years.
moreExamples: The bridge collapsed because it had been deteriorating for decades.
They divorced because they had been arguing for months.
The team won because they had been training intensively.
The business succeeded because the owners had been working hard.
The building was demolished because it had been standing empty.
useCases.note: Use to provide background context for past events by showing ongoing situations.

useCases.title: Predictions Based on Opinion
useCases.mainExample: I think it will rain tomorrow.
moreExamples: She will probably pass her exam.
The team won't win the match.
I think he will like this present.
They will be late, I'm sure.
I don't think she'll come.
useCases.note: Use WILL for predictions based on personal opinion (what you THINK will happen).

useCases.title: Spontaneous Decisions
useCases.mainExample: I'll have the chicken, please.
moreExamples: It's cold. I'll close the window.
The phone's ringing. I'll answer it.
I'm thirsty. I'll get some water.
We're out of milk. I'll buy some.
That looks heavy. I'll help you carry it.
useCases.note: Use WILL for decisions made AT THE MOMENT OF SPEAKING (not planned before).

useCases.title: Offers & Promises
useCases.mainExample: Don't worry, I'll help you.
moreExamples: I'll call you tomorrow, I promise.
I'll carry your bags for you.
I'll pick you up at 7pm.
I won't tell anyone, I promise.
I'll be there on time, don't worry.
useCases.note: Use WILL to make offers, promises, and guarantees.

useCases.title: Threats & Warnings
useCases.mainExample: If you don't study, you'll fail the exam!
moreExamples: Be careful, or you'll hurt yourself!
If you're not careful, you'll break it.
Watch out, or you'll fall!
If you don't hurry, you'll miss the train.
If you touch that, you'll burn your hand.
useCases.note: Use WILL in warnings and threats (often with 'if' or 'or').

useCases.title: Requests & Invitations
useCases.mainExample: Will you help me with this?
moreExamples: Will you come to my party?
Will you marry me?
Will you open the door for me?
Will you pass me the salt, please?
Won't you sit down?
useCases.note: Use WILL in questions to make polite requests and invitations.

useCases.title: Refusals (Won't)
useCases.mainExample: The car won't start.
moreExamples: The door won't open.
He won't listen to me.
My computer won't turn on.
The child won't eat his vegetables.
The window won't close.
useCases.note: Use WON'T for refusals (something/someone refuses to do something).

useCases.title: Future Facts
useCases.mainExample: She will be 30 next year.
moreExamples: The sun will rise at 6am tomorrow.
Christmas will be on a Friday this year.
The meeting will be in Room 5.
The course will last six months.
The flight will take three hours.
useCases.note: Use WILL for facts about the future (things we know are certain).

useCases.title: First Conditional (Real Future)
useCases.mainExample: If it rains, we will stay at home.
moreExamples: If you study hard, you will pass.
If she calls, I will tell her the news.
If they arrive early, we will go to the beach.
If he asks me, I will say yes.
If we have time, we will visit the museum.
useCases.note: Use WILL in the main clause of First Conditional (if + present simple, will + infinitive).

useCases.title: Actions in Progress at Future Time
useCases.mainExample: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
moreExamples: At 8pm tonight, we will be having dinner.
Next week, I will be working from home.
Tomorrow at this time, she will be taking her exam.
At 3pm, they will be watching the match.
This time next year, we will be living in a new house.
useCases.note: Use for actions that will be IN PROGRESS at a specific future time.

useCases.title: Polite Questions About Plans
useCases.mainExample: Will you be using the car tomorrow?
moreExamples: Will you be going to the shop later?
Will you be passing the post office?
Will you be attending the meeting?
Will you be staying for dinner?
Will you be needing this?
useCases.note: Use Future Continuous for POLITE questions (less direct than 'will you use').

useCases.title: Future Plans as Background
useCases.mainExample: I can't come because I'll be working.
moreExamples: Sorry, I'll be sleeping at that time.
I can't help tomorrow because I'll be studying.
She won't join us because she'll be traveling.
They can't come because they'll be moving house.
I won't be available because I'll be in a meeting.
useCases.note: Use to give reasons or excuses based on future arrangements.

useCases.title: Expected Future Events
useCases.mainExample: Don't phone after 11pm - I'll be sleeping.
moreExamples: This time next month, she'll be celebrating her birthday.
By next year, they'll be running the company.
In ten years, we'll be teaching robots.
Soon, everyone will be working from home.
In the future, people will be living on Mars.
useCases.note: Use for events we expect to happen as a natural result of circumstances.

useCases.title: Temporary Future Situations
useCases.mainExample: I'll be staying with friends while my house is being renovated.
moreExamples: She'll be using her brother's car for a few weeks.
They'll be living in a hotel during the conference.
He'll be working in London temporarily.
We'll be renting while we look for a house to buy.
I'll be taking the bus while my car is being repaired.
useCases.note: Use for temporary situations that will be in progress for a limited period.

useCases.title: Avoiding Direct Commands
useCases.mainExample: You'll be wearing your uniform tomorrow.
moreExamples: You'll be starting your new job on Monday.
They'll be attending the training session.
She'll be submitting her report by Friday.
You'll be following these instructions.
We'll be implementing the new policy next month.
useCases.note: Use Future Continuous to soften instructions/commands (sounds less direct than 'You will wear').

useCases.title: Parallel Future Actions
useCases.mainExample: While you're shopping, I'll be preparing dinner.
moreExamples: While she's studying, he'll be working.
While they're traveling, we'll be looking after their house.
While you're in the meeting, I'll be finishing the report.
While he's presenting, we'll be taking notes.
While the children are sleeping, we'll be watching a film.
useCases.note: Use for TWO actions that will happen at the SAME TIME in the future.

useCases.title: Predictions About Future Habits
useCases.mainExample: In 20 years, people will be driving electric cars.
moreExamples: Soon, everyone will be using AI assistants.
In the future, students will be learning online.
Next year, more companies will be offering remote work.
By 2030, we'll all be using renewable energy.
In ten years, doctors will be using robot surgeons.
useCases.note: Use for predictions about ongoing activities or habits in the future.

useCases.title: Completed by Future Time
useCases.mainExample: By next year, we will have been married for ten years.
moreExamples: She will have finished by 5pm.
They will have left before you arrive.
I will have completed the course by June.
He will have read all the books by the end of the month.
We will have moved house by Christmas.
useCases.note: Use for actions that will be COMPLETED before a specific future time or event.

useCases.title: Future Achievements
useCases.mainExample: By the age of 30, she will have visited 50 countries.
moreExamples: By 2030, scientists will have found a cure for cancer.
By next year, he will have written three novels.
By the end of the decade, they will have built 100 schools.
By retirement, I will have worked for 40 years.
By midnight, we will have raised Â£10,000.
useCases.note: Use to talk about achievements or milestones reached by a future deadline.

useCases.title: Before Another Future Action
useCases.mainExample: I will have left before you get here.
moreExamples: She will have gone to bed before he arrives home.
They will have finished dinner before the film starts.
We will have cleaned the house before the guests come.
He will have submitted his application before the deadline.
The train will have departed before we reach the station.
useCases.note: Use when one future action will be completed BEFORE another future action.

useCases.title: Assumptions About Now
useCases.mainExample: They will have arrived by now.
moreExamples: She will have heard the news by now.
He will have finished work by now.
The film will have started by now.
They will have left by now.
The shops will have closed by now.
useCases.note: Use Future Perfect to make assumptions about things that have PROBABLY already happened.

useCases.title: Predictions with Evidence
useCases.mainExample: Look at those clouds! It will have started raining by the time we get home.
moreExamples: At this rate, she will have spent all her money by Friday.
If he continues like this, he will have failed all his exams.
By the end of the day, I will have walked 20,000 steps.
If we don't hurry, the shop will have closed.
By tomorrow, everyone will have heard about it.
useCases.note: Use to predict completion based on current evidence or trends.

useCases.title: Completed Stages in Projects
useCases.mainExample: By Friday, we will have finished the first phase.
moreExamples: By next month, they will have completed the construction.
By the deadline, I will have submitted all the documents.
By June, she will have graduated.
By the end of the quarter, we will have met our targets.
By tomorrow, he will have reviewed all the applications.
useCases.note: Use to talk about completed stages or milestones in long-term projects.

useCases.title: Time Limits & Deadlines
useCases.mainExample: You must finish by 5pm. Otherwise, the office will have closed.
moreExamples: Submit it today. By tomorrow, the deadline will have passed.
Book now. By next week, all the tickets will have sold out.
Apply soon. By next month, the position will have been filled.
Buy it today. By Monday, the sale will have ended.
Register early. By then, all the places will have been taken.
useCases.note: Use to warn about deadlines or consequences if action isn't taken in time.

useCases.title: Experience Up to Future Point
useCases.mainExample: By the time I'm 40, I will have lived in five different countries.
moreExamples: By next year, she will have worked here for 20 years.
By the end of the course, you will have learned 2000 words.
By retirement, he will have taught thousands of students.
By June, I will have been to the gym 100 times this year.
By her 50th birthday, she will have run 10 marathons.
useCases.note: Use to talk about accumulated experience or achievements up to a future point.

useCases.title: Duration Up to Future Point
useCases.mainExample: By 2025, I will have been working here for ten years.
moreExamples: Next month, she will have been studying English for five years.
In June, they will have been living in London for a decade.
By the end of the year, he will have been teaching for twenty years.
Next week, we will have been waiting for a month.
By tomorrow, I will have been working on this for 48 hours.
useCases.note: Use to emphasize the DURATION of an action up to a specific future time.

useCases.title: Continuous Activity Before Future Event
useCases.mainExample: When I finish this book, I will have been reading for six hours!
moreExamples: When we arrive, we will have been traveling for 20 hours.
When she graduates, she will have been studying for four years.
When the match ends, they will have been playing for 90 minutes.
When he retires, he will have been working for 45 years.
When we finish, we will have been working for 12 hours straight.
useCases.note: Use to show how long an activity will have been continuing by a future event.

useCases.title: Explaining Future Situations
useCases.mainExample: She'll be exhausted tomorrow because she will have been working all night.
moreExamples: They'll be tired because they will have been traveling for days.
He'll be experienced because he will have been doing it for years.
I'll be ready because I will have been preparing for months.
You'll understand because you will have been studying it for weeks.
We'll be experts because we will have been practicing for ages.
useCases.note: Use to explain future situations by showing the ongoing activity leading up to them.

useCases.title: Predictions About Ongoing Actions
useCases.mainExample: By next year, they will have been building that house for three years!
moreExamples: By the time it's finished, we will have been waiting for months.
By Friday, I will have been working on this report for two weeks.
By the end of the day, she will have been driving for eight hours.
By midnight, he will have been playing video games for six hours.
By summer, they will have been renovating for a whole year.
useCases.note: Use to predict how long an ongoing action will have continued by a future time.

useCases.title: Emphasis on Repetition Over Time
useCases.mainExample: By the end of the month, I will have been calling you for weeks!
moreExamples: By Friday, she will have been asking the same question for days.
By next week, they will have been sending emails for a month.
By tomorrow, he will have been trying to fix it for hours.
By the deadline, we will have been requesting this for months.
By the time you respond, I will have been waiting for ages.
useCases.note: Use to emphasize REPEATED actions over a period leading to a future point.

useCases.title: Milestones & Anniversaries
useCases.mainExample: In July, we will have been living together for 25 years.
moreExamples: Next month, I will have been running this business for a decade.
In 2026, they will have been married for 50 years.
By Christmas, she will have been working here for a year.
Next week, we will have been learning together for six months.
By my birthday, I will have been studying French for two years.
useCases.note: Use to highlight duration milestones and anniversaries in the future.

useCases.title: Assumptions About Future Progress
useCases.mainExample: By now, they will have been traveling for about 5 hours.
moreExamples: By this time tomorrow, we will have been driving for 12 hours.
By the time you read this, I will have been working for hours.
By 8pm, she will have been cooking for three hours.
By now, he will have been waiting for at least an hour.
By the time they arrive, we will have been preparing for days.
useCases.note: Use to make assumptions about how long something will have been in progress.

useCases.title: Future Complaints & Frustrations
useCases.mainExample: If he doesn't call soon, I will have been waiting for a week!
moreExamples: If she doesn't finish soon, we will have been here for hours!
If they don't respond, I will have been emailing them for months!
If this continues, we will have been dealing with this problem forever!
If you don't hurry, I will have been standing here all day!
If he doesn't arrive soon, I will have been waiting all evening!
useCases.note: Use to express future frustration about how long something will have been continuing.
